turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 52, S. Edward Bloom versus Illinois.
Mr. Eben have you concluded your argument, you have?
Had you not?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: May I please the Court.
I had terminated my opening as of yesterday.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes I understood that.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Thank you Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Hladis.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
During the course yesterday afternoon's argument by counsel for the petitioner, he made two observations with which we must take issue.
One relates to the factual aspect of this case and the second relates to the law on the issue as it has been announced by this Court.
We address ourselves first to the factual aspect.
The key or the simple facts in this case are not many.
The decedent died on the 6th of July 1964.

On the 14th of July 1964, this petitioner drafted and caused the execution of a will of this dead person dated June 21, 1964 and on the 11th of August 1964, he presented his will for admission to probate in a probate division in Cook County and in this petition stated that the decedent had died on the 6th of July.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is he beneficiary?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No sir, he was not.

The record will show and our statement of facts indicates that it had actually began with a practical nurse by the name of Pauline Owens would increase her legacy in this fraudulent will from $20,000 and a valid will to $40,000 in this will.
Now the important consideration for the purposes of this case is this, yesterday the counsel referred to the alleged filing of a spurious will and two other alleged contemptuous acts.

We submit gentlemen that on the basis of the record at this time and on the basis of the record as it was made in the Courts of Review in the State of Illinois it is improper for a counsel to refer to alleged contemptuous conduct because this petitioner has not only failed to challenge the sufficiency of the finding of guilt but he affirmatively conceded in the Supreme Court of Illinois that the findings of guilt were amply supported by the evidence.
Now we understand that the briefs filed by all parties are a part of the certiorari filed in this Court.
That concession is found at page 15 of the petitioner's brief and the concession is also noted in the opinion of the Supreme Court of Illinois.
Now what we are getting at is this, the case is here before this Court on the issue as to whether or not he was entitled to a jury trial.
But the very issue, the very point which a jury could give him to wit the finding of guilt or non-guilt, the finding of guilt or innocence is not challenged and has never been challenged.
The second observation --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There was a challenge at the trial, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Beg pardon sir?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There was a challenge at the trial, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: In the sense that he cross-examined the prosecution witnesses.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Pleaded not --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: He pleaded not guilty, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, isn't that a challenge?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That is a challenge, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then he did at some time challenge it.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: He did it at the trial but the point is that after the finding of guilty was in, he did not challenge, not only did not challenge but he did concede that the findings were supported by the evidence.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but aren't there issues here of alleged trial errors in respect to the psychiatric testimonies --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: He makes no --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- and he (Voice Overlap) and there's something, I've forgotten --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: You're talking about the amicus curiae report.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, yes is that -- no, I'm not -- in addition to that am I wrong?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: And then the third observation he makes as the remark of the assistant state's attorney who have made reference to the fact that the petitioner did not take the stand.
Now as to the first, the amicus curiae report that is a practice that has been approved by the Supreme Court of Illinois.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: No I think the reference maybe to your adversary's statement yesterday that testimony of the psychiatrist was abused to show that the petitioner could not possibly have committed this crime assuming to that effect.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that -- that would indicate that there was some sort of a contest at the trial level.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Oh, we're not quarrelling the fact that there was a contest at the trial level.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well what is your point then, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: The point is this that once the finding --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Not prejudicial error, what is it?
What is your point?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: The point is that what he wants today, it would seem to me that if I were in the petitioner's position and I were asking this Court to formulate a constitutional doctrine whereby I'd be guaranteed a jury trial in a criminal contempt case pursuant to the Sixth Amendment as it would be imposed upon our course by the Fourteenth Amendment that I would at least come up here where the bona fide contest on the findings of guilt.
But he didn't even do that --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I don't (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: -- in the Courts of Review in the State of Illinois sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I confess that I still don't follow you.
Are you saying that there was a contest on the issue of guilt but not a substantial one, is that your point?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: What I am saying is that after the finding was made, he not only did not challenge the sufficiency but he actually conceded that the evidence was sufficient to support the findings.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know but I thought you said yesterday and as I read his brief, it's an issue he thought of malevolent intent, is that the language which he says is important and that psychiatric test to only bears on it and that he could not have been guilty of the offense because the psychiatric testimony might have persuaded the jury, indicated that he did not have the necessary malevolent intent which -- as I understood your argument.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That is correct.
That was advanced sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But even if he raise no question -- any square attack on the findings, your argument would apply to any other trial error.
And you want to raise a trial error you better accompany it with a challenge to the facts.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I would think so.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Because I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That just doesn't --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Gentlemen, I think he'd -- if he has a case, I don't think it's a Sixth Amendment case.
I think what he's actually complaining about is the extent of the punishment and that would be our solution to the problem, it's a Fourteenth Amendment problem.
The issue on the case as we have it here is not whether he should have been given a jury trial.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well let's just assume that if -- let's just assume that in the federal system for example, a man demands a jury trial in a criminal case and is denied.
And the judge finds him guilty and he comes up solely on the refusal of the jury trial.
Would you say to him that -- would you say to him, “No, your challenge can't be sustained because you don't challenge the finding of guilt”?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No, I would not Mr. Justice White for a different reason though, because it's clearly established under the Sixth Amendment and under Article III that any criminal case, he is entitled to a jury trial.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's exactly what he's claim is here that under the Sixth Amendment --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No.
Well, what he's doing here is asking this Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Surely --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: -- to formulate a new doctrine --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: -- one which has never been formulated before which even in Cheff has contrary to his representation has no constitutional basis at all and is asking this Court to say now under the Sixth Amendment criminal contempt cases shall have jury trials and will impose it on the state by virtue --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What you're really saying is a kind of an (Inaudible) argument.
The case is (Inaudible) as unappealing to this from your standing problem.
This Court should not ceasefire to (Inaudible) basic constitution doctrine, isn't that what you're saying?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well, that is not the only reason that we would say it Your Honor because we --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: This facet of your argument comes after that.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That is correct, that is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What do you have to say about the fact that this is also a felony under the laws of Illinois, forgery?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Yes it is.
I don't see any inconsistency between the two at all.
We have here --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Wouldn't it be inconsistent if you had a choice of trying the man for the same act, one with the jury and one without?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No, by the very nature of the two proceedings.
And the one you have contempt which is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But do you take the position they could also be charged with forgery?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: It is possible, but I say that as far as Cook County is concerned that will not happen and as a matter of fact, the statute has run in this particular case.
But we have had rare instances where contempts have been committed usually in a probate level which are also felonies.
And in all cases where the probate judge has gone to the way of contempt, the state has not prosecuted criminally and we did not do it here and we don't -- certainly don't intend to do it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Who's -- makes the choice?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: In this case the errors themselves made the choice.
They are the ones that began.

They asked for the appointment of the amicus curiae and they filed a first petition or rule to show a cause and then the judge determined that there was probable cause after he had received the amicus curiae report and the contempt proceeding began.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well isn't the contempt proceeding easier than going to a grand jury and trying the case before a jury?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I would think it's easier and I would think it is much more effective and that is undoubtedly what the probate judge wanted to achieve in this particular case.

Because you're talking about a court in a large metropolitan area and as we all know much of the practice in a probate division is done what I might call on an ex parte basis because many times the interested party do not have counsel, they rely upon counsel for the personal representative.
And the Court must rely upon the integrity, upon the honesty of the attorneys presenting matters to them.
And whereas in this case, you have a situation where a fraudulent will was presented for admission and sought to be processed while the Court has a real problem as far as discipline is concerned.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do you have a double jeopardy provision in your state constitution?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Yes we do sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Supposing (Inaudible) statute of limitation describing the process, this fellow, could he plead and -- his contempt conviction in regard of that (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I don't think he could Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I think strictly speaking, the doctrine of double jeopardy doesn't apply.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I think they're strictly speaking the doctrine of double jeopardy would not apply --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: -- to a criminal contempt.
I just don't think it would apply, its not a crime.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Suppose there is an uproar in the Court then, someone was murdered and the judge determined instead of having him indicted -- a person indicted for murder, he charge him with criminal contempt, could he try him for the murder and contempt?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I imagine possibly he might -- well, that's not a probability actually Your Honor, I --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, why is it?
This -- what's the difference between forgery and murder if they're both statutory crimes and they are felonies?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Because of the gravity between the two.

I mean one is -- that the forgery in this particular instance have to do with the very operation of the Court whereas certainly the murder would cause a disturbance in the Court but I just cannot visualize that the -- a probate Judge would move by way of contempt rather than have it in turn, the matter over the state for prosecution under the murder statute.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's why we're here today.

Some people think that forgery is a pretty important case and particularly when a man goes to jail for -- goes to penitentiary for years and they think they can't understand why it should be done in this way rather than give a man a jury after an indictment.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well, Mr. Chief Justice, I gave what we submit as a good practical sound reason in this particular context and that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But we're not dealing with practical reasons, particularly we're dealing with the law in this case.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I understand but by the same token, that probate judge down there has to serve a notice upon the bar that he cannot tolerate practices such as we had here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well do you think it wouldn't be serving a notice on them if he called it detention of the grand jury and the grand jury indict him and he was convicted of forgery and sent to the penitentiary on what you say is absolutely conclusive evidence, wouldn't he trust a jury?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I don't think that as far as he was concerned it would be as effective.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I mean, if we -- would probably feel that he would deliver a better message to the bar then refer it all to the grand jury.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And then he uses his personal feelings in the matter to determine whether he wants to punish him on his own trial rather than to trust it to a jury.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well, whether we want to call it feelings or what or convictions but those are his views.
And of course, here, as I pointed out before is the fact that the proceedings were actually initiated by the error, the lawful errors themselves.
This is not something that was done completely on his own volition.
The --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which do you think would be worse, to be disbarred or fined $2000?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Which would I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On the life of the individuals.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: The fine?
Which would be worse?
Disbarment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Disbarment, why?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Disbarment.
Well, I think all of us as lawyers are pretty proud of our license and we do not want to be placed in a position of ever losing it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Not merely because of a foul of it, is it?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's not merely he's out of it, is he?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I think that is one of the elements, yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But isn't the main thing is his life's vocation is -- what (Inaudible) says, "You've taken away that which is the most valuable thing perhaps to many lawyers have in the world".

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I agree with you.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And yet you say that he should not be considered as a criminal offense.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well I don't, I don't know whether this contempt would conform the fair basis --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why do they call it criminal?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: As against civil?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why is it called criminal contempt?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I think the reason that it's called criminal contempt is the fact that the Court as an agency of the public is actually in the -- is the agent of the public and that the public's dignity is offended by specific conduct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And it's taking away from him if he is disbarred, is it not?
Far more that it would be if they took away his home or a large part of his property.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well, of course Mr. Justice Black we are assuming that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, isn't it a not more valuable to him than his home would be?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Oh, yes, I would --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or a large part of his property.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: As far as I -- personally I'm concerned, it would be, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In the Illinois --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But how can you not face the fact as it is, that it amount everywhere in the world that a human being can think of pragmatically that one of the worse punishments that can be inflicted on a human being.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Are you speaking of disbarment now sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Disbarment.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: The disbarment.
I can't quarrel with that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What's the rule in Illinois, is conviction over felony automatic disbarment or not?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: It's not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It's not?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: It is not, no.
The disbarment proceedings are conducted through grievance committees of the Bar Association --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I assume (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: -- to the commissioners --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I assume that but if he's convicted of a felony as the usual procedure that he is disbarred.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No, it's not automatic disbarment.
He has his hearing --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Usual was my word.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No it's not even that sir.
And he asks this hearing before the Supreme Court of Illinois.
And as against disbarment, there may be censure, there may be suspension and there of course may be dismissal of charges.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There, they have automatic disbarment (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I'm not aware of any.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No, there are no -- I'm not aware of any --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There is a rule as far as disbarment is concerned as to the defendant's proceeding.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That is correct.
Excuse --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was this man disbarred?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No, I understand he is actively practicing at the present time.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He just got two years in jail?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That's right.
And he's practicing.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I wonder why if the -- if that the prime concern of the Court was that the dignity of the profession and the dignity of the Court should be upheld and he went so far as to deprive a man of a jury trial and an indictment -- a trial after an indictment, he would do this and not pursue it further and not having a disbarment proceeding.
Why would that be?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: The proceedings in this case are -- there's nothing extraordinary about it.
The committee is awaiting the outcome of the case and as a matter of fact I had a call from the Secretary about 10 days ago on the matter and that is usual in all cases.
They will wait until the case is finally disposed before it is taken up by the committee acting on behalf of the Supreme Court of Illinois.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, we just had one here the other day where the Bar of Illinois moved against a person who never have had any charge against him.
I'm speaking of Steel Workers Union case here.
And we had to reverse that case but they didn't wait there for this case to be decided and the person hadn't committed any crime.
But he just said that he was violating the ethics of the profession.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well, the reason that they didn't wait there for this case to be decided is the fact that they are moving against that union and particularly the group that was servicing them with professional legal services is the very fact which gave rise of the case as I recall it.
You're talking about the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Wasn't the illegal practice of the law here the very thing that caused his trial for contempt?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I would say the -- I mean you want to call that illegal practice, I would say the presentation of a fraudulent will and imposing up on the Court is the thing which brought about his contempt --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, yes.
Well, that's -- let's phrase it your way but isn't that just as important as certainly is the one we have here?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I don't know what you're getting at Mr. Chief Justice, I mean the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I mean this, you started your whole argument by saying that the judge was so concerned with the honorable practice of law in his court and the bar was so interested in the ethics of the profession that the Court appointed an amicus to go out and investigate this whole thing and they found that he had perpetrated this fraud upon the Court.

And now if that is true why wouldn't the bar move there when he was convicted in the court below and when he was convicted by your Supreme Court just as they did in the Steel Workers case where there wasn't any charge of fraud at all, it was just illegal practice of law.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well, I think that we have two different situations in the Steel --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Of course they are different but --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: The Steel Workers situation gave rise to the lawsuit which eventually wound up in this Court.
Whereas this case, what the Bar Association is doing and the Grievance Committee specifically is waiting for the final determination.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright, that's your answer.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Yesterday afternoon when counsel for the petitioner was analyzing the fast law of the question specifically the Green and the Barnett cases and Cheff, he made a statement regarding the decision of the majority of this Court in Cheff versus Schnackenberg with which we do not agree.

This Court will recall that the majority in both Green and the Barnett is held at criminal contempts are not crimes, and as such, they do not fall within the purview of the -- either the Sixth Amendment or the Third Article of the Federal Constitution.

Then counsel moves on to the Cheff decision and suggest to this Court that an important modification was made therein by the majority and that the requirement of a jury trial in federal cases wherein sentences exceed six months has been raised to a constitutional level.
We have read that that is an argument that is made by the petitioner in his brief and was repeated yesterday.

We have disagreed with that argument and we still adhere to our position that at no time as the majority of this Court ever said either that criminal contempt was a crime and that as such it fell within the purview of the Sixth Amendment and the Third Article of the Federal Constitution.
Cheff --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you have a statute in Illinois against contempt?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No we do not sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No statute at all?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No.
And as a matter of fact, contempts are expressly excluded from the criminal code.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there any limit on the amount of time?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No there is not sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you take the position you'd give a man 20 years without it too?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No I don't, I don't.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But do you take five?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That would depend upon the case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Five would be alright?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That's right.
But on our theory, I would have much less trouble than on theirs.
I like to take your example one step further.
Let us take 20 years and let us assume that the man was given a jury trial.
Could I in all sincerity and honesty stand here and defend that sentence of 20 years?
I think not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, it's not this case.
But I'll assume what's the time of the -- the maximum penalty for forgery.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: One to 14.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well suppose this Court gave him 15, would that be alright?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Where a no -- no jury trial?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I would have trouble with the case but not on his theory but on the Fourteenth Amendment approach --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't I have just so much trouble --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: -- to defend --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't I have just much trouble with the two years?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Because then under the doctrine of basic fair play which after all is the core of the Fourteenth Amendment, this Court could as we suggested in Green.
Examine whether or not the trial judge here had abused his discretion.
It is our view that after this Court examines the evidence in the context it will find that the discretion was not abused in sentencing the gentleman with two years.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What is the situation in Illinois with respect to entitlement to jury trial?
Is there a dividing line, a misdemeanor -- what do you call it under your Illinois system?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: We have a -- we do not have a petty offense.
We have a misdemeanor which is determined by the amount of punishment that is anything a year under (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: A -- one year or under?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And there, you're not entitled to a jury.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No, but they are -- accord a jury trials, when they request them, they accord a jury trial.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: On request, you can --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- get one.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is that in any misdemeanor?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: As far as I know, yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: The jury courts in the police level.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that what you have here is that as a system -- general system of law of judicial administration and the way in Illinois of which anybody who was tried for a misdemeanor meaning and offense in which the maximum punishment is a year is not automatically entitled a jury trial to make -- get it on request.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: On request.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But if he is tried for felony meaning where the punishment is at the excess of a year or maybe an excess of a year is entitled a jury trial.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That is correct.
He can either request it or waive it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do I understand you to say that in Illinois it's discretionary with the Court as to whether a man --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No it is not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- be given a jury in a misdemeanor case or does he have the right to demand a jury trial if he wants one?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: As I understand it sir, he has the right to demand a jury trial.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And he is entitled to have it?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In a misdemeanor case?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: And he receives it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's a little different, isn't it --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- from what you just said?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I think I said the same thing to Mr. Justice Fortas.
I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh, no.
You said he may have one, but it's different, he's entitled to one if he wants it.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well, when I said he may, what I meant was that he can request it and then receive it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you permit defendants to be tried by -- without a jury in felony cases?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Oh, yes but of course the waiver --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then what's the difference?
He demands it from both of them, he gets it.
He demands a felony case, he gets it.
If he demands a misdemeanor, he gets it.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what's the difference?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: None.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I just thought the import of what you said to Justice Fortas was a little different as between --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No, I didn't intend to setup any distinction.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
I'm mistaken then.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The fact here is that in Illinois, any time you do to a man has a consequence of some of this conduct.
What was done in this case to a man where all admit that the punishment of disbarment was the most serious things that can appear, you take that one clash of cases out and deny him a jury trial?
That's the fact, isn't it?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: I didn't -- I'm sorry sir, I didn't hear the first part of your observation.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He was not disbarred here of course --

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No he's not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- but he could be.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: He could be, yes.
That would be dependent upon the judgment of the Supreme Court of Illinois in their disciplinary proceedings.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if you call it a misdemeanor or a felony -- you name a misdemeanor or a felony, he's entitled to a trial by jury.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: If he requested it, he would get it.
Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's a kind of anachronism that's gone out of history, isn't it?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Well, whether we call it anachronism --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, but that's may be the wrong thing.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Yes, but the fact of the matter is that contempt has always been regarded.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, by some.
Has always been a scrambling position of that by the judiciary which has been contested most frequently by the legislative mind.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: There -- I will concede that there is difficulty on the part of someone to accept the prevailing view that it is sui generis and does enjoy this unique position.
There are as you well know Mr. Justice Black, those who feel that it should be equated to the status of a crime and that all the privileges should --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It feel that he should be treated as what it is with that regard to its name?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Hladis, does your Illinois constitution have a jury trial probation?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What does it say?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: Substantially, what the federal constitution says that the -- in crimes that the people are entitled to a jury trial.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does it make any distinction between misdemeanors and felonies?

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: As far as I recall, no sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And does your judge made law make any distinction between it.

turn.speaker: edward_j_hladis
turn.label: Mr. Edward J. Hladis
turn.text: No.
I see my time is up, gentlemen.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
In response to Chief Justice's last question we have set forth the exact constitutional provisions of the Illinois statute on page 2 of our original brief in this Court.
There are two Sections really which covered in Illinois.
Article II, Section 5 provides that the right of trial by jury as here before enjoined shall remain in (Inaudible).
Article II, Section 9 says, “In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall have the right to a speedy public trial by an impartial jury.

Nevertheless in Illinois over the years, there has grown up a body of law which I frankly concedes to the Court which has consistently withheld from criminal contender's a right to trial by a jury which I analyzed incidentally in my brief before the Supreme Court of the State to show that it grew as somewhat in topsy like fashion and was based upon a forced premise which originated in a pure civil contempt case where of course it's quite proper to deny trials by jury.

And based upon that fragile basis, they grew with Illinois the body of law to which I have just referred and to which the Illinois Supreme Court still adheres in this case dismissing the holding of this Court in Cheff v. Schnackenberg with -- I use to word advisedly to stay in almost making only passing reference to it.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, Cheff and Schnackenberg is a federal case and so far at least, so far the Illinois practice has been identical to the practice through and through both the federal cases and state cases by this Court and (Inaudilbe).

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Yes, I would say --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Nothing unusual about what Illinois has done.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: You're quite right Mr. Justice Harlan.
Up until now, they have adhere to Green and Barnett and in fact rely upon it again in their decision in this case, the case at bar.
And we're critical of that of course when we say that they have failed to recognize the important modifications in Green and Barnett as now written by this Court in Cheff.

Incidentally, I revisited Green after the colloquy I had with the Court yesterday and I am able to say that the Court that there was no criminal statute involved in Green in effect at the time of the alleged contemptuous acts.
The defendant there had been convicted of a crime and jumped and he refused to obey an order.
As he jumped down, he refused to obey an order to surrender and he was tried on contempt for disobedience of that order.
And as Mr. Justice Harlan wrote in the majority opinion of that case, he observed that the bail jumping statute had not yet been enacted.

It had been enacted in 1990 -- in 1954 whereas the contemptuous acts -- the acts complained off occurred in 1951 and passed it on to the Court because I received the impression probably incorrectly yesterday that there was a contention that there was a criminal statute at to time.One other thing, counsel refers to the fact that in the Supreme Court of the State of Illinois we conceded guilt.
And Mr. Justice White's observation on it of course I thought was quite correct.
That is that we contested right from the very beginning of course by reason of our plea of not guilty.
But when we got to the Supreme Court of the State upon the record, I did not plan to engage in a long argument based upon the sufficiency of the evidence since the trial judge waived the evidence.
He was the trier of the fact, he waived the evidence, he judged the credibility of the witnesses and so on.
Oh, I did not, however concede in the Supreme Court of the State that there was just no other side to it.

I said incidentally in brief that the page referred to by Mr. Hladis, in a footnote that the defendant concedes that the people's evidence when viewed on appeal as it must be viewed on appeal in the light most favorable to the people that the evidence was sufficient to support the Court's judgment because it's quite true.

And I also said in our brief here on page 2, I said the petitioner did not challenge the sufficiency of the evidence of the Illinois Supreme Court in view of the rule prevailing in that state that a verdict will not be disturbed on appeal when there is any evidence which when taken with its intendments most favorable to an appellee tends to prove the essential allegations of the complaint.

I would, I submit most respectfully to the Court that a complete waste of time to me on this record to go up and say that our psychiatrist should have been believed, the psychiatric evidence established.

As Mr. Justice Brennan says that the malevolent intent necessary to a criminal contempt was not shown but we had an attorney who represented an adversary party in the trial court proceedings testified in the trial.

A cross-examination that when he thought with the petitioner prior to the time that he would open or present the spurious will, he was convinced and this is in the record that the petitioner did not realize the involvements he was getting into.
It did not have the mind, my own language to understand his predicament at that time.
All of which within, but this was disregarded of course by the trial court.

And I point out although it -- only been touched on briefly by Mr. Hladis that one of the complications in this case is this amicus curiae secret report which we have referred to as the fink report since the amicus curiae was a Mr. Fink.
I like to think that the word is descriptive incidentally by the card here but in any event, the -- that report found its way into the trial court's chambers.
It was viewed there in camera and he has refused to make it part of the record here in this case although we asked for an order on it.
So it still remains secret.
We don't know what's in it.
And it compounds the fact that we would deny the jury.

Had we had a jury would be bad enough for the trial court to have such a report anyway if you can visualize a Federal District Court judge with FBI reports at his chambers before he proceeds to a trial -- a case if it's so much similar to this.
But where the trier of the fact is that person and I think additional emphasis should be given to (Inaudible) and that is one of the errors we complained about.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you mind telling us how this amicus report came into being please.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Yes sir.
The proceeding originally began in the probate court of Cook County upon the presentation of a petition to the Court by -- as under a prior will who would have been out under the spurious will.
In it, they alleged and it's in the record incidentally with -- and you can refer to it at the proper time.

In it, they alleged that they sought fraud was being perpetrated upon the Court by the presentation of this other will and they specifically asked the trial court for the appointment of an amicus curiae for the purpose of investigating and prosecuting if necessary the fraud involved.
The trial court read at that motion and appointed Mr. Fink.

Thereafter, I think within approximately 60 or 90 days, the trial court entered an order upon the amicus curiae requiring him to file his report with the trial court and such a report was filed and was held in camera by the Court.

Now the record incidentally on that shows when we made a demand for it prior to trial and then again at trial, now the Court, page 81 of the record said, “It is not a part of the record, it belongs to the Court itself and the Court will turn it over to you and you will be at liberty to read it as concerns any witnesses testimony.
The Court wants to get at the truth or falsity at the proceeding so I will turn it over to you and you may use it for cross-examination”.

And it was, portions of it were turned over to me somewhat in Jenks style, that is where a witness took the stand who was referred to in the fink report then I was entitled to cross-examine there on the basis of that.
But that was not the entire report.

There is no way that we can show it to the Court where -- there is no way that we can indicate to the Court whether or not we are prejudiced which was the grounds relied upon by the Illinois Supreme Court for denying us a relief in that -- in connection with this particular point but I submit to the Court that it was impossible under the circumstances here for us to get such a report to determine whether or not we had been prejudiced since the trial judge himself to which (Inaudible) significance, refused to give it to us and refused to put it in the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was the contempt judgment based in whole or in part on that report?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: We cannot tell Mr. Justice Black.
We cannot tell.
I do not know frankly what use was made of it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: When was the complaint and contempt filed in relation to the filing of that report?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Afterwards, it was filed by the state's attorney and there were series of them.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It was --

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: First --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- filed by the state's attorney in the contempt case?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Yes sir, that's represented by Mr. Hladis.

The -- after this petition to which I referred to before have been filed then and after the fink report have been filed then there was a petition filed by the state's attorney seeking to have the petitioner to show cause why it should not be held in contempt.
Thereafter, they filed an amended petition after that had been attacked and it was upon the amended petition that the trial ultimately was had.
But in direct answer to Your Honor, the petitions relating to contempt were filed after the receipt of the so-called fink report.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Eben, this petitioner has not served any of his sentence yet, hasn't he?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: No sir, no Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Does the Illinois procedure in a criminal contempt case permit an appeal from sentence?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Oh, yes, yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So that the appellate court might have reduced this sentence on appeal from the sentence even though it left the finding of guilt undisturbed, might it?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: I think that it might but not the appellate court but if you use it in a --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I mean your appellate court --

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: -- particular sentence made by --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Ordinarily I take it in Illinois as -- is generally the case, there's no appeal from a sentence in a criminal case.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Unless a constitutional question is involved.
We went directly to the Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes but otherwise, there's no appeal from the sentence to have the sentence modified or reduced even though the finding of guilt stands --

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: That's right

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- in New York.
That's right.
But that's not true in the criminal contempt case you could have appealed to have this sentence reduced even though the finding of guilt remain?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: I -- as a matter of fact Mr. Justice Brennan, I wrote a part of my brief in the Illinois Supreme Court on that point asking them to at least reduce the sentence to conform with this Court's decision in Cheff.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Although I'm not sure that my position is really too sound because in Cheff as I pointed out yesterday, you do have that Section 18, Title I defining petty crimes and we don't have anything like that in Illinois at all.
A defense is either a misdemeanor or it's a felony.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, did you have any Illinois authorities in which an appellate court had reduced the criminal contempt sentence?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you have -- you don't have that?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: No sir.
In fact, I'm not sure that there are (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Did the Illinois Supreme Court address itself to that part of your brief?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: They addressed itself to the question of the two-year sentence without considering the facet which Your Honors is now discussing.
They discussed it in terms of Cheff and they said really that what a sentence is, it's not at all relevant to whether or not it should be a jury trial.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you if your case depends at all on your judgment on whether this Court decides the federal constitution was right to a trial by jury as by the Fourteenth Amendment been made applicable to the states?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: That's correct.
We believe that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was it your case depend on a holding to that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: I'm sorry Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does your case depend on a holding to that effect here, your case?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: My case depends upon if I understood Your Honor correctly, the application of the Fourteenth Amendment to state courts in a long line of decisions.

I think I counted 23 of this Court in the last few years as well as an application of recently written by the Court in which you for the first time so far as I know, reach out to define what criminal proceedings are for the purpose of imposing constitutional rights at the Bar Association disciplinary proceedings.

The juvenile proceedings, the Colorado Sex Offenses if you remember which were regarded as civil there, I know its three or four others which you -- this Court now regards as criminal in the sense that they require the application of certain constitutional rights.

And I say of course if in a disbarment proceeding or even a proceeding where a man loses his license under a municipal ordinance which this Court has decided if that is to be considered criminal providing for the application of constitutional rights then certainly conduct which is labeled right at the name criminal contempt and which of itself constitutes the violation of the state statute is felony should certainly be considered a criminal proceeding.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the question I was asking was this, do we have to decide -- is your case so far as you have claimed a right to trial by jury is concerned dependent on whether the Fourteenth Amendment made the right to trial by jury in the federal courts applicable to the states.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: My answer is to the affirmative.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You say we do.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You say we do have to face that question?

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: I think that the Fourteenth Amendment is involved.

I have struggled with it and that has not yet occurred to by mind a way in which the problem could be treated without applying the constitutional inhibition to the states and the only way I think we could do that would be under the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well there is -- is a -- there may be an alternative may there not and that is, does it, for this Court to consider whether a jury trial should have been made available in this particular type of criminal contempt in view of the fact that the state does -- has adapted a jury trial system and that that jury trial system would embrace the right to a jury trial if this -- if the petitioner here have been prosecuted for forgery under the criminal statute.

Now is it possible that that is an alternative theory to the one about which Mr. Justice Black was questioning you namely that the -- your -- that the jury trial provision in the Sixth Amendment does apply to the states by virtue of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: I would certainly accept that as the alternative.
If I understand Your Honor, I think you're referring to an interpretation of the Illinois constitution rather than the federal constitution would be, yes, I'll accept that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: anthony_bradley_eben
turn.label: Mr. Anthony Bradley Eben
turn.text: Thank you very much.
